I've performed the web search you requested about Harry Potter family belonging themes, orphan status, found family, friendship, literary analysis, home, and identity. The search returned comprehensive results covering various aspects of these themes throughout the Harry Potter series.

Here are the key insights from the search results:

## Family and Belonging Themes

Belonging to a family shapes our sense of identity and Harry was never treated as being part of the Dursley family. The Dursleys are Harry's only living blood relatives, but the concept of family extends beyond shared blood.(no content)When McGonagall welcomes the first years to Hogwarts, she tells them that "the Sorting is a very important ceremony because, while you are here, your House will be something like your family within Hogwarts"(no content)Two months into his first year at Hogwarts, "the castle felt more like home than Privet Drive ever had"

## Orphan Identity and Found Family

Harry reveals the realities of being an orphan. There are issues of not knowing how to love and connect with others through identity, the feeling of taking on the world alone, and no sense of purpose.(no content)Going to Hogwarts introduced Harry to a cast of characters that led him to a world filled with love, respect, identity, and family. At the end of the series, Harry is no longer an orphan, but among a family that gives him the love and respect that is given to one in a family.

## Friendship as Core Theme

At the center of The Sorcerer's Stone is the importance of love from both family and friends.(no content)The basis of the friendship between these three characters lies with their shared experiences. All three are shunned by the other students at some point in the story and are ridiculed due to their family situations: Harry for being an orphan, Ron for growing up in a poor family, and Hermoine for being a mudblood, or born to parents who don't have magic.

## Identity and Self-Discovery

Harry's struggle to understand his own identity and find a place where he truly belongs is a recurring motif throughout the books.(no content)Harry's transition from the non-magical "Muggle" world to the magical world parallels his transition from the isolation and dejection of feeling different to the beauty and excitement of finding a place where he belongs.

## Home and Symbolic Belonging

The stark contrast between the "mounds of gold coins" inside Harry's vault and his lack of currency in the Muggle world represents the wealth that comes from having a family. In Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, Harry realizes that Voldemort hid Hufflepuff's cup inside Bellatrix's vault because he saw the bank "as a real symbol of belonging to the wizarding world"

The search results reveal how J.K. Rowling masterfully weaves these themes throughout the series, showing Harry's journey from an isolated orphan to someone who finds his true family through friendship and belonging in the wizarding world.
